publications.title: The ECM and tissue architecture are major determinants of early invasion mediated by E-cadherin dysfunction
publications.authors: S. Melo , P. Guerrero , M. Moreira Soares , J. R. Bordin , F. Carneiro , P. Carneiro , M. Beatriz Dias , J. Carvalho , J. Figueiredo , R. Seruca
publications.description: Germline mutations of E-cadherin cause Hereditary Diffuse Gastric Cancer (HDGC), a highly invasive cancer syndrome characterised by the occurrence of diffuse-type gastric carcinoma and lobular breast cancer. We used vitro assays and mathematical models to show that defective cell-to-cell links, abnormal ECM interaction, and the structure of gastric glands contribute to increased cancer cell invasion.

publications.title: TrajPy: empowering feature engineering for trajectory analysis across domains
publications.authors: M. Moreira-Soares, E. H. Mossmann, R. D. M. Travasso, J. R. Bordin
publications.description: This submission presents TrajPy, an open-source Python package that empowers feature engineering for trajectory analysis across different domains. TrajPy provides users with a set of optimized algorithms and metrics for trajectory clustering, classification, and visualization, allowing the identification of patterns and trends that are often overlooked by traditional methods. The package is user-friendly and flexible, allowing customization and integration with other Python libraries. TrajPy is expected to become a valuable tool for research in multiple fields, including biology, computer science, and social sciences.

Estevez-Priego, M. F. Cabrera-Umpierrez, I. Alonso, S. Copelli, A. Ness, M. Pring, K. Hurley, BD4QoL Consortium
publications.description: This article presents the clinical study protocol of a multicenter randomized trial focused on quality of life assessment using non-invasive intelligent tools during post-curative treatment follow-up for head and neck cancer. The study aims to evaluate the impact of these tools on patients' well-being and their potential role in improving treatment outcomes.

publications.title: Multi-Phase-Field models for biological systems: From cells to vessels.
publications.description: The process of metastasis formation begins by the movement of a single cell when it emerges from the tumor colony. This cell crosses the basement membrane penetrating a blood vessel and enters in the bloodstream. Physics is more and more present in the research of cellular mechanics, particularly in the study of processes related with tumor growth. In this project we will use continuous media and soft matter physics to model tissue invasion by metastatic cell in a quantitative way.

publications.title: Coupling blood flow and growing vasculature in three dimensions
publications.description: We used continuum mechanics coupled with an agent-based approach to model angiogenesis - the growth of new blood vessels from a preexisting vasculature. The model was implemented in 3D and the code is available as open source.
